metadata.titleEn: Gridded pollen-based Holocene regional plant cover in temperate and northern subtropical China
metadata.description:
The Regional Estimates of Vegetation Abundance from Large Sites (REVEALS) model was developed by Sugita (2007) to correct for bias due to inter-taxonomic differences in pollen productivity and dispersion and estimate plant cover at a regional spatial scale based on pollen records. We provide the dataset of pollen-based REVEALS reconstruction for temperate and northern sub-tropical China over the Holocene. The REVEALS reconstruction was achieved using 94 selected pollen records from lakes and bogs at a 1˚x1˚ spatial scale and a temporal resolution of 500 years between 11.7 and 0.7 ka BP, and three recent time windows (0.7˗0.35 ka BP, 0.35˗0.1 ka BP, and 0.1 ka BP˗present). 
The dataset of pollen-based REVEALS reconstruction of Holocene plant cover for the study region includes the REVEALS proportions of plant cover (and related SEs) for 75 1˚x 1˚grid cells and 25 time windows for each grid cell for 27 taxa, two alternatives of aggregation of plant taxa to PFTs: ten PFTs and six PFTs, and three land-cover types. The metadata files providing details on the sites used in the REVEALS reconstruction for each grid cell and each time window. For instance, the original site names, modern vegetation zones, geographical coordinates (latitude and longitude in decimal degrees), elevation in meters above sea level, site types (bog or lake), basin sizes (radius and area), number of 14C radiocarbon dates or other types of dates, approximate temporal extent of the site. The dataset is suitable for palaeoclimate modeling, can be applied also in evaluating simulations of past vegetation from dynamic vegetation models and anthropogenic land cover change (ALCC) scenarios.
metadata.instructions:
The dataset of pollen-based REVEALS estimates of Holocene plant cover for temperate and northern sub-tropical China comprises four csv files with the REVEALS proportions of plant cover (and related SEs) for 75 1˚x 1˚grid cells and 25 time windows for each grid cell for 27 taxa (Data1.plants.csv), 2) six PFTs (Data2.6PFTs.csv), 3) three land-cover types (Data3.LCTs.csv) and 4）ten PFTs (Data4.10PFTs.csv). The grid_cell column in the data table is represented as coordinates of left bottom corner, time_window column shows the interval between the starting and end time of the data compiled for reconstruction, e.g. 100-350 represent 350-100 BP (before present). Four additional files are complementing various information for the REVEALS dataset. Such as the metadata (Table S1, pollen data for details), the details on the sites used in the REVEALS reconstruction for each grid cell and each time window (Table S2), three Land-cover types (LCTs) and six plant functional types (PFTs) and their corresponding pollen morphological types (Table S3), and finally ten plant functional types (PFTs) and their corresponding pollen morphological types Table S4.
Scientific paper of the 10 PFTs has been published in Li et al. (2020). Paper for the rest of the data will soon be published.

background: Vegetation has undergone changes all over the globe throughout the Holocene as a result of climate change from the early Holocene on and disturbance from anthropogenic activities from the mid-Holocene on. Pollen data mapping can provide insights into temporal and spatial vegetation changes at broad continental scales. However, the quantification of past vegetation changes based on fossil pollen data is necessary to answer specific research questions on the relationship between plant cover and e.g. climate or biodiversity. Techniques such as biomization and the modern analogue technique (MAT) have been widely applied to reconstruct past continental-scale changes in vegetation cover. These techniques have the disadvantage that they cannot quantify the cover of individual plant taxa. The possible effects of anthropogenic land-cover (LC) transformation due to past land-use (LU) changes (LULC changes) on the Holocene climate is still an issue of debate. Current earth system models (ESMs) take care of the climate–land vegetation interactions by coupling a dynamic vegetation model (DVM) with the climate model. DVMs simulate climate-induced (natural) vegetation. Therefore, past LULC changes have to be estimated to study their effect on past climate. The anthropogenic land-cover change (ALCC) scenarios most commonly used by palaeoclimate modellers are those from the HYDE database and the KK10 dataset of past deforestation. These scenarios are based on a number of assumptions for population growth, per-capita land use, and other parameters that influenced land use over time in the past. Therefore, a current priority is to produce datasets of pollen- and archaeology-based data of past LU and LC that can be used in palaeoclimate modelling or the evaluation of DVMs and ALCCs. Several reconstructions of the biomes and vegetation cover of China during the Holocene are available. However, these reconstructions do not provide quantitative information on the spatial extent of deforested land within woodland biomes or of vegetation types including both trees and herbs.
research objective: The objective is to provide a dataset of pollen-based land cover for the last ca. 12 millennia that is suitable for palaeoclimate modelling and for the evaluation of simulated past vegetation cover from dynamic vegetation models and anthropogenic land-cover change (ALCC) scenarios. In this paper, we present the first pollen-based quantitative reconstruction of Holocene plant-cover changes in temperate and northern subtropical China using the Regional Estimates of VEgetation Abundance from Large Sites (REVEALS) model.
challenges: The quality of the REVEALS reconstructions is mainly reliant on the input data (pollen count quality and size), reliability of the chronologies of pollen records and the relative pollen productivities used, type and size of the pollen sites (lakes or bogs), number of pollen records used for reconstruction in each grid cell, and variation between pollen counts within a grid cell. REVEALS was intended for pollen records from large lakes. Pollen records from bogs violate the model’s assumption that no plants are growing on the surface of the deposition basin. The uncertainty in the RPP estimates used is another factor influencing the reliability of the REVEALS reconstructions. The number of values available in the calculation of the mean RPP estimates and the locations of the RPP studies in terms of vegetation zones are provided in Table 1. The REVEALS model estimates the proportion of each plant taxon in relation to the total cover of all taxa with the RPP estimates available (in this case, 27 taxa) rather than its actual cover if all existing taxa could be considered.
methods: The REVEALS reconstruction was achieved using 94 selected pollen records from lakes and bogs at a 1°×1° spatial scale and a temporal resolution of 500 years between 11.7 and 0.7 ka and in three recent time windows (0.7–0.35 ka, 0.35–0.1 ka, and 0.1 ka to present). The dataset includes REVEALS estimates of cover and their standard errors (SEs) for 27 plant taxa in 75 1°×1° grid cells distributed within the study region. The 27 plant taxa were also grouped into 6 plant functional types and 3 land-cover types (coniferous trees CT, broadleaved trees BT, and C3 herbs/open land (C3H/OL)), and their REVEALS estimates of cover and related SEs were calculated.
dataset: The dataset includes REVEALS estimates of cover and their standard errors (SEs) for 27 plant taxa in 75 1°×1° grid cells distributed within the study region. The dataset of gridded pollen-based REVEALS estimates of plant cover for temperate and northern subtropical China presented in this paper is based on the REVEALS estimates published in Li et al. (2020). It includes, for 25 consecutive time windows of the Holocene, cover estimates for 27 plant taxa that are further grouped into estimates of cover for 6 plant functional types (PFTs) and 3 land-cover types (LCTs), i.e. coniferous trees (CT), broadleaved trees (BT), and C3 herbs/open land (C3H/OL).
findings: The REVEALS reconstructions suggest that the cover of Poaceae, Cyperaceae, and Rosaceae during the Holocene is often equal to or larger than the cover of all remaining 11 herbs together, although the cover provided by Artemisia and Amaranthaceae/Chenopodiaceae can also be relatively large. There is a consistent increase in CT cover in most grid cells over northern China during the first half of the Holocene, with maximum values occurring sometime between 8 and 5 ka (the timing depends on the region), before a steady decline in the values of CT cover. The changes in cover of BT during the Holocene show similar trends to those for CT: a steady increase during the first half of the Holocene, with the highest values found in the time windows from 8.2–7.7 to 5.2–4.7 ka (depending on the region), followed by a steady decrease through the late Holocene.

Verification.Question: Is the REVEALS model primarily intended for use with pollen records from large lakes?
Does the REVEALS dataset include cover estimates for both plant functional types and land-cover types?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the key challenges in data collection for quantitative reconstruction of Holocene plant-cover changes using the REVEALS model?
Concept Completion.Answer: quality of pollen count data, reliability of pollen record chronologies, relative pollen productivities, type and size of pollen sites, variation between pollen counts within a grid cell

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the pollen records collected from for the REVEALS reconstructions in temperate and northern subtropical China?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that quantifies past vegetation changes using pollen data?
Example.Answer: The REVEALS model is an example of a data collection method that quantifies past vegetation changes by transforming pollen assemblages into estimates of vegetation cover. It considers pollen productivity of different species, pollen dispersal, and the influence of sediment basin size and type on pollen source areas.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using pollen records from bogs in vegetation reconstruction?
Example.Answer: One challenge faced when using pollen records from bogs is that they can violate the assumptions of models like REVEALS, which assume no plants are growing on the surface of the deposition basin. This can affect the reliability of the vegetation reconstructions.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate a type of dataset that includes estimates of plant cover and their standard errors for specific taxa in a defined region?
Example.Answer: A dataset of gridded pollen-based REVEALS estimates includes cover and standard errors for 27 plant taxa in a specified region, grouped into different plant functional types and land-cover types, distributed across 1°×1° grid cells. This dataset is used to reconstruct Holocene plant-cover changes in temperate and northern subtropical China.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main factors influencing the quality and reliability of pollen-based vegetation reconstruction datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: input data quality, reliability of chronologies of pollen records, relative pollen productivities used, type and size of pollen sites, number of pollen records used for reconstruction in each grid cell, variation between pollen counts within a grid cell, uncertainty in the relative pollen productivity estimates

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics define the resolution and temporal scope of pollen-based datasets for Holocene vegetation cover changes?
Feature Specification.Answer: 1°×1° spatial resolution, 500-year temporal resolution between 11.7 and 0.7 ka, 350-year resolution from 0.7–0.35 ka, 250-year resolution from 0.35–0.1 ka, 100-year resolution from 0.1 ka to present

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features are included in the metadata of pollen-based vegetation reconstruction datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: names of reconstruction sites, modern vegetation types, number of chronological records, latitude, longitude, elevation, size and type of sedimentary basins

Quantification.Question: How many grid cells are included in the pollen-based REVEALS dataset for temperate and northern subtropical China?
What is the temporal resolution for the REVEALS reconstruction dataset during the period of 11.7 to 0.7 ka?

Definition.Question: What is the REVEALS model in the context of quantitative vegetation reconstruction?
Definition.Answer: The REVEALS model refers to a method for quantitative vegetation reconstruction based on pollen data. It involves converting pollen assemblages into estimates of vegetation cover by accounting for factors such as differential pollen productivity of plant taxa, pollen dispersal abilities, and the impact of sediment type and basin size on the pollen source area. This approach aims to produce more accurate reconstructions of past vegetation cover.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with using pollen data for reconstructing past vegetation cover?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in using pollen data for reconstructing past vegetation cover include reliance on the quality of input data such as pollen count and size, accuracy of pollen record chronologies, and the relative pollen productivities used. Additional challenges involve the type and size of pollen sites, the number of pollen records per grid cell, variation between pollen counts, and the assumption that no plants grow on the surface of deposition basins in the case of bogs.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods in the REVEALS model compare with those used in the biomization and modern analogue technique (MAT) for reconstructing past vegetation cover in terms of spatial and temporal resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The REVEALS model uses high-quality pollen records from lakes and bogs at a 1°x1° spatial scale with a temporal resolution of 500 years for most of the Holocene and increased resolution in recent times. In contrast, biomization and MAT often do not provide quantitative cover information for individual plant taxa and may have limitations in spatial and temporal resolution.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in challenges faced by the REVEALS model and dynamic vegetation models (DVMs) when used for simulating past vegetation cover changes?
Comparison.Answer: Both the REVEALS model and DVMs face challenges related to the accuracy of input data and assumptions. The REVEALS model's challenges include reliance on pollen count quality, chronology reliability, and assumptions about pollen productivity and deposition sites. DVMs simulate natural vegetation and must estimate past land-use changes for accurate climate interactions, facing challenges in representing anthropogenic influences accurately.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do datasets of pollen-based land cover using the REVEALS model differ from those based on the HYDE database and KK10 dataset in terms of assumptions and data sources?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets using the REVEALS model are based on pollen data and aim to provide quantitative reconstructions of past vegetation cover, considering different taxa and their relative productivities. In contrast, the HYDE database and KK10 dataset rely on assumptions about population growth and land use over time, often lacking specific pollen-based data inputs and focusing on broader land-cover change scenarios.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges in data collection, such as the reliability of chronologies and the size/type of pollen sites, impact the interpretation of reconstructed vegetation cover?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in data collection, including the reliability of chronologies and the type and size of pollen sites, significantly impact the interpretation of reconstructed vegetation cover. These factors affect the quality of the REVEALS reconstructions, as inaccuracies in pollen counts or inappropriate site characteristics, like using bogs where the assumption of no plant growth on the deposition surface is violated, can lead to unreliable vegetation cover estimates. Thus, careful consideration of these variables is crucial for accurate interpretations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the reliability of REVEALS reconstructions in estimating vegetation cover?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The reliability of REVEALS reconstructions is influenced by factors such as the quality and size of pollen counts, the reliability of the chronologies of pollen records, the accuracy of relative pollen productivity estimates, the number of pollen records used per grid cell, and the type and size of pollen deposition sites. Additionally, variations in pollen counts within a grid cell and the assumption violations in pollen records from bogs also affect reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using pollen records from bogs instead of large lakes on the quality of vegetation cover reconstructions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using pollen records from bogs could violate the REVEALS model's assumption that no plants are growing on the surface of the deposition basin, potentially affecting the reliability of vegetation cover reconstructions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the uncertainty in relative pollen productivity (RPP) estimates impact the results of pollen-based land cover reconstructions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Uncertainty in RPP estimates can influence the reliability of the REVEALS reconstructions as they affect the estimated proportion of each plant taxon in relation to the total cover of all taxa.

Causal Consequence.Question: If fossil pollen data from multiple sites are used for reconstruction in each grid cell, what could be the impact on the variability of pollen counts within those grid cells?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using fossil pollen data from multiple sites may result in variation between pollen counts within a grid cell, which could affect the consistency and accuracy of the reconstructed vegetation cover.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to create a dataset of pollen-based land cover for the last 12 millennia in temperate and northern subtropical China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to provide a dataset of pollen-based land cover for the last ca. 12 millennia that is suitable for palaeoclimate modelling and for the evaluation of simulated past vegetation cover from dynamic vegetation models and anthropogenic land-cover change (ALCC) scenarios.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address input data quality and uncertainties in the REVEALS reconstructions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The quality of the REVEALS reconstructions is mainly reliant on the input data quality, including pollen count quality and size, reliability of the chronologies, and the accuracy of relative pollen productivities. Addressing these factors is crucial to ensure the reliability of REVEALS reconstructions, as uncertainties in these estimates can influence the outcomes of the reconstructions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in utilizing the REVEALS model for quantitative reconstruction of vegetation cover using fossil pollen data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The REVEALS model requires the selection of high-quality pollen records from lakes and bogs, determination of the relative pollen productivity for different taxa, and estimation of plant cover using spatial grids. The model considers the type and size of pollen deposition sites and uses temporal windows for different periods to achieve a quantitative reconstruction of vegetation cover.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers address the challenges of uncertainty in relative pollen productivity estimates when using the REVEALS model for vegetation reconstruction?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers can address these challenges by ensuring a large number of values in the calculation of mean relative pollen productivity estimates and carefully selecting the locations of studies within relevant vegetation zones. This helps improve the reliability of the reconstructions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps should be followed to compile a dataset of pollen-based land cover suitable for palaeoclimate modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To compile such a dataset, researchers should collect and verify pollen data from reliable sources, apply the REVEALS model to estimate vegetation cover, and group the data into appropriate plant functional types and land-cover types. It is essential to maintain temporal consistency across the Holocene and ensure the inclusion of standard errors for each estimate to facilitate its use in palaeoclimate modeling.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or features are necessary for reliable REVEALS model reconstructions of vegetation cover?
Enablement.Answer: Reliable REVEALS model reconstructions require high-quality input data, accurate chronologies of pollen records, reliable relative pollen productivities, appropriate type and size of pollen sites, and sufficient pollen records within each grid cell.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of pollen data mapping enable insights into temporal and spatial vegetation changes at broad continental scales?
Enablement.Answer: Pollen data mapping enables insights into temporal and spatial vegetation changes by providing quantitative reconstructions of plant-cover changes over millennia, which are suitable for palaeoclimate modeling and evaluation of dynamic vegetation models and anthropogenic land-cover change scenarios.

Expectation.Question: Why might the REVEALS model produce unexpected results in estimating vegetation cover during certain periods of the Holocene?
Expectation.Answer: The REVEALS model's results depend heavily on the input data quality, including pollen count quality, size, and the reliability of the chronologies of pollen records. Variations in these factors and the assumptions about pollen records from different types of sites can lead to unexpected results.

Expectation.Question: Why would the reconstruction of past vegetation cover using pollen data face challenges in accurately representing land-cover changes over time?
Expectation.Answer: Reconstructing past vegetation cover using pollen data can be challenging due to the reliance on assumptions about pollen productivity and dispersal, the type and size of deposition sites, and the uncertainties in Relative Pollen Productivities (RPP) estimates that influence the reliability of the reconstructions.

Expectation.Question: Why is it critical to improve datasets of past land use and land cover changes for palaeoclimate modeling?
Expectation.Answer: Improving datasets of past land use and cover changes is crucial because current earth system models depend on accurate data to simulate climate-induced vegetation changes and assess the impacts of anthropogenic land-cover transformation on past climate scenarios. Existing scenarios often rely on assumptions that may not fully capture the complexities of historical land use.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using the REVEALS model for quantifying past vegetation cover changes in China during the Holocene?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using the REVEALS model for quantifying past vegetation cover changes in China during the Holocene is reliant on several factors, including the quality and size of pollen count data, the reliability of pollen record chronologies, the accuracy of relative pollen productivity estimates, and the type and size of pollen sites. Despite these challenges, the REVEALS method provides a quantitative reconstruction that is suitable for palaeoclimate modeling and evaluating dynamic vegetation models and anthropogenic land-cover change scenarios.

Judgmental.Question: What are the primary challenges associated with collecting high-quality pollen data for use in vegetation cover reconstructions?
Judgmental.Answer: Primary challenges include ensuring the quality of pollen counts, maintaining reliable chronologies of pollen records, obtaining accurate relative pollen productivity estimates, and selecting appropriate types and sizes of pollen sites. Additionally, the number of pollen records used for reconstruction in each grid cell and the variation between pollen counts within a grid cell also pose significant challenges.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from lakes and bogs can be equally used for vegetation cover reconstruction when they might have different deposition characteristics.
Assertion.Answer: The REVEALS model was originally intended for pollen records from large lakes, as it assumes no plants are growing on the deposition basin's surface. Using pollen records from bogs can violate this assumption, potentially affecting the reconstruction's quality. The model's reliability depends on factors such as the type and size of the pollen sites and the variation in pollen counts within a grid cell.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the challenges of utilizing pollen data for quantitative vegetation reconstruction and how they are addressed in data collection methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the quality and size of pollen count data, reliability of pollen record chronologies, relative pollen productivities, type and size of pollen sites, and variations in pollen counts within grid cells. These are addressed by selecting high-quality pollen records from lakes and bogs and utilizing the REVEALS model to estimate vegetation cover while considering relative pollen productivities.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to achieve high temporal resolution in pollen-based vegetation cover datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involve using 94 selected pollen records at a 1°x1° spatial scale, achieving temporal resolutions of 500 years between 11.7 and 0.7 ka, and then increasing the resolution to 350 years, 250 years, and 100 years for more recent time windows. This approach provides detailed insights into vegetation changes over time.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest potential strategies for refining datasets of Holocene plant-cover changes using pollen data.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies include increasing the number of pollen records used for reconstruction in each grid cell, improving the accuracy of relative pollen productivity estimates, and expanding the geographical coverage of pollen data collection sites to ensure diverse representation of different vegetation zones.
